body: As I'm gearing up to plan my topics course for spring, I'm looking for websites of courses on computational topology (or any variant of the subject ... applied algebraic topology ... topological data analysis, etc.).
seed.title: Computational Topology / TDA Courses

body:
Carola Wenk writes:
The Department of Computer Science at Tulane University is seeking PhD students for its Interdisciplinary PhD Program in Computer Science that focuses on the application of computer science and its principles to other areas. The Interdisciplinary PhD Program is an individualized program that consists of graduate training in computer science and another area. This interdisciplinary area can be chosen from other disciplines at Tulane that offer a PhD, including biology, economics, linguistics, mathematics, and psychology.

PhD positions are available for this program to begin in Fall 2016. PhD students receive full financial support in the form of teaching and research assistantships with a generous stipend, including paid tuition.

For more information about the Interdisciplinary PhD Program in Computer Science visit:
http://tulane.edu/sse/cs/academics/graduate/interdisciplinary-phd-program.cfm

Current interdisciplinary research in the department includes artificial intelligence, computational social choice, computational biology, computational geomet
seed.title: Interdisciplinary PhD positions available at Tulane University

body:
http://www.jobs.ac.uk/job/AMN933/research-fellow-in-data-analysis/

Mathematics, Statistics and Machine Learning for Data Analysis

Applications are invited for up to four research positions supported by an EPSRC grant "Joining the dots: from data to insight"                       (http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/NGBOViewGrant.aspx?GrantRef=EP/N014189/1).   This programme will develop a powerful synthesis of methods from topology, statistics and machine learning for applications in medicine and computational chemistry.

The positions arise in the context of a new exciting interdisciplinary programme developed at Southampton by a team of scientists from Mathematical Sciences, Computer Science, Medicine and Chemistry under the umbrella of the Institute for Life Sciences. The work will cover a wide range of problems from developing new data analytic methodology, algorithmic implementations, to specific applications. Our exemplar applications include clinical studies of asthma (in collaboration with U-BIOPRED, the largest asthma research consortium in the world) and computational mol
seed.title: Research fellow in Data Analysis at Southampton

On January 22 we shall have workshop "Applied Algebraic Topology" at Queen Mary, University of London. 
There will be 4 talks given by:

Ginestra Bianconi (QM)
Heather Harrington (Oxford)
Martin Liebeck (Imperial) 
Dirk Schuetz (Durham) 

The talks will start at 10 am and the workshop will be closed at 16.30. 
For more information about the workshop please contact Michael Farber (M.Farber@qmul.ac.uk).

The workshop is supported by a grant from the London Mathematical Society.

body:
In the function ripsDiag (R package TDA), there is a variable maxscale that (from what I understand) is (related) to the maximum value of the epsilon parameter (radius of sphere) in the rips filtration. A large choice creates too big simplicial complexes and the computer runs out of memory. On the other hand, a small value misses topological features. I've also noted that there is an interplay between number density and maxscale value for the evaluation of the Betti numbers (in general high density point clouds tend to need smaller values for maxscale).

For example

    library("TDA")
    XX <- circleUnif(30)
    maxscale <- .1 
    maxdimension <- 1
    Diag <- ripsDiag(XX, maxdimension, maxscale, printProgress =     
    TRUE,dist="euclidean",library="Dionysus")

misses the betti_1=1 topological feature. This is captured for maxscale > 1.0. On the other hand for 1000 random points on the unit circle,

XX <- circleUnif(1000)
maxscale <- 0.1 
is sufficient for the ripsDiag to catch all topological features. If I use here the used value from the manual for the case of 30
seed.title: Optimum maxscale parameter value for cloud points

body:
Prospects in Data Science – A multidisciplinary symposium
Set in the heart of the gorgeous New Forest, this Data Science Symposium organised by the University of Southampton brings together a multi-institutional, high-profile panel of speakers to promote the cross-fertilisation of ideas between the different domains of Data Science, particularly Statistics, Mathematics and Computer Science, and data practitioners from both academia and industry.
Confirm speakers include:
John Aston (University of Cambridge)
Gunnar Carlsson (Stanford University)
Fai Cheng (Lloyd's Register Group)
Dave Coplin (Microsoft UK)
Mark Girolami (University of Warwick)
Arthur Gretton (University College London)
Peter Grindrod (University of Oxford)
Yike Guo (Imperial College London)
Wendy Hall (University of Southampton)
David Hand (Imperial College London)
Vitalyi Kurlin (Durham University)
Jane Naylor (Office for National Statistics)
Sofia Olhede (University College London)
Nigel Shadbolt (University of Oxford)
Anne Trefethen (University of Oxford)
Frank Woods (University of Oxford)
Dates: 12-14
seed.title: Symposium: Prospects in Data Science @ Southampton

body:
A position is available for a PhD student in topological data
analysis (TDA) / computational topology under the supervision of Brittany Terese Fasy at Montana State University.  Applicants must hold a bachelor's or master's  degree (or equivalent) in computer science, mathematics, statistics, or a 
related field.  The applicant should have a good knowledge of algorithms, 
and discrete mathematics.  Strong mathematical ability is required, but specific knowledge of topology is not necessary to apply.  Students with an interest in interdisciplinary research will be preferred.

Dr. Fasy's research combines mathematics and computer science.  Often, the research begins with a motivating example.  The 
[TDA community at MSU](http://www.cs.montana.edu/brittany/research/TDA-flyer.pdf)
 is growing, and spans across multiple colleges.  Dr. Fasy has a joint lab with two other faculty members, Dr. Brendan Mumey and Dr. Mike Wittie.  Their lab, the 
[Network + Algorithms Lab](http://www.cs.montana.edu/brittany/research/NAL-flyer.pdf)
 works on a diverse set of research questions rela
seed.title: Grad Students Wanted!

body:
Dan Isaksen <isaksen@wayne.edu> writes to ALGTOP-L: 

Wayne State is searching for a tenure-track position in statistics or related areas this year.  If you work in topological data analysis, I suggest that you to apply at mathjobs.org.  The official announcement is below.  Feel free to contact me for more information.

********************************************************************** *******

The Department of Mathematics at Wayne State University invites applications for a tenure-track or tenured position at the Assistant Professor, Associate Professor, or Full Professor level, commencing in fall, 2016. The Department is especially interested in hiring in statistics or related areas, but exceptional candidates from any area of mathematics are invited to apply. Applications should include a signed, detailed vita, description of current research interests, and four letters of recommendation, one of which should address teaching. Solid evidence of effective teaching at the undergraduate level is preferred to a statement of teaching philosophy. A Ph.D. in statistics o
seed.title: Wayne State

body:
Applicants are invited for two postdoctoral positions at the interface of theoretical neuroscience and algebraic topology or applied algebra. An ideal candidate is a mathematics Ph.D. with background in areas such as algebraic topology, geometry, or commutative algebra. Prior familiarity with neuroscience is not required, but interest in learning the relevant background is expected. The postdoctoral fellow will engage in the development of novel mathematical methods for understanding neural coding and neural networks.

To apply for this position, please submit your application via the mathjobs.org website in response to the job ad http://www.mathjobs.org/jobs/jobs/7575

Further information can be received from vladimir.itskov@math.psu.edu. 
See also http://sites.psu.edu/mathneurolab/ for more information.  

The closing date for applications is November 15, 2015.
seed.title: Postdoctoral positions at Penn State

*Upcoming events of interest:*
Nov 7 - Workshop on Topology: Identifying Order in Complex Systems, IAS
Nov 14-15 - AMS Special Session on Topological Data Analysis: Computations, Statistics, and Applications, Rutgers University
seed.title: TDA Events in the greater NYC area

body:
(posting on behalf of Michael Farber)

We invite applications for a fully funded 3 years' PhD studentship commencing in January 2016. The research project will deal with developing new topological and geometric algorithms for video data compression and with other problems of analysis of large data. The project will be sponsored by the Queen Mary, University of London and by the Penteract 28 and will be supervised by representatives of both institutions. The candidates must have basic knowledge of pure and applied mathematics; it is desirable that the candidates are familiar with geometry, topology, statistics, elements of computer science and data analysis.

The deadline for applications is: November 16, 2015.

The application procedure is described at

http://www.qmul.ac.uk/postgraduate/research/subjects/mathematical-sciences/index.html

For further enquiries please contact Prof. Michael Farber <m.farber@qmul.ac.uk> or Dr Danijela Hora <danijela.horak@gmail.com>.
seed.title: PhD Studentship in Mathematics

body:
We would like to compute persistent diagrams of gray-scale digital images obtained from (micro) ct-scans.  How can we convert such a digital image to a input file (e.g boundary matrix, persistent pairs) format? 

Here is the specific format in 2D that we are interested in. 

2 : this is the dimension of the cubical grid 
3 : this is the number of cubes along the first dimension 
4 : this is the number of cubes along the second dimension 
1 : this is the birth time of the 2D cube anchored at (0,0) 
2 : this is the birth time of the 2D cube anchored at (1,0) t
1 : this is the birth time of the 2D cube anchored at (2,0) 
2 : this is the birth time of the 2D cube anchored at (0,1) 
-1 : this indicates that there is no cube anchored at at (1,1) 
2 : this is the birth time of the 2D cube anchored at (2,1)   

It is taken from the Perseus project webpage of Vidit Nanda and similar to persistence_pairs-ascii format.  For more info one can check http://www.sas.upenn.edu/~v
seed.title: Converting a digital image to an input file (e.g. boundary matrix)

seed.title: SVM on Concatenated Lambdas

body: At our small, undergraduate institution, it is always a struggle to get enough students to offer our introductory topology course.  With the growth of computational topology and topological data analysis, it has occurred to us that incorporating applications into our topology course might make it more attractive to students.  If anyone has already made or is planning such a modification to a first undergraduate topology course, my colleagues and I would be very interested in hearing about it.
seed.title: Applications in undergraduate topology course
